EN

Mark Dow, a macro trader and former IMF economist famous for shorting the 2017 Bitcoin peak, has expressed his desire for the cryptocurrency to collapse to zero. He stated that he wants to see the total annihilation of the industry to punish "grifters" who he claims used fearmongering and false promises of wealth to defraud investors. Dow views the current market as a result of manipulation and hopes those responsible face financial ruin. Despite successfully closing his short position near the 2018 bottom of approximately $3,200, Dow remains a vocal Bitcoin permabear. Critics point out that his long-standing skepticism has proven costly, noting that Bitcoin has rallied by 133,000% since he once labeled the asset a "tax on paranoid stupidity." While his 2017 trade was well-timed, his continued hostility towards the crypto space highlights a deep ideological divide.

Key Points

  • Mark Dow wants Bitcoin to go to zero to punish promoters and scammers in the industry.
  • He attributes the 2017 bubble burst to CME Futures and closed his profitable short position at the bottom of the 2018 bear market.
  • Critics highlight Dow's long-term bearish bias, noting Bitcoin has surged 133,000% since he called it a 'tax on paranoid stupidity'.

Article

The hedge fund manager and economist who famously shorted the 2017 top is rooting for the total annihilation of the cryptocurrency industry to punish the "grifters." Mark Dow, the macro trader and former IMF economist best known for calling the Bitcoin top in 2017, has offered his harshest condemnation of the industry to date. Dow is now actively wishing for the asset to evaporate completely. HOT Stories "I want bitcoin to go to zero," Dow declared. "And I want all the grifters who pumped this to rubes on the back of moronic fearmongering of monetary policy and promises of generational wealth to be fully invested as it happens." Dow gained some prominence after famously announcing that he had shorted Bitcoin back in December 2017. He wrote that Bitcoin’s price had become "random" and disconnected from any reality, He noted that the introduction of CME Futures provided the catalyst for the bubble to pop, given that institutional bears could finally bet against it. In December 2018, almost exactly one year after opening the short, Dow closed the position near the absolute bottom (approximately $3,200). “I’m done. I don’t want to try to ride this thing to zero,” he said back then. A broken clock? Despite his president trades, which could have been pure luck, Dow’s takes should be taken with a grain of salt, given that he has been a Bitcoin permabear for well over a decade. At the same time, some industry proponents have dug up an old tweet by Dow, in which he claims that Bitcoin is a tax on paranoid stupidity. Since then, the world’s largest cryptocurrency rallied by 133,000%.
